 CHAPTER I BACKGROUND A. INTRODUCTION 1.1 Lithuania is the largest of the Baltic republics, with a territory of 65,200 sq km and a population of nearly 3.7 million people. During the Soviet era, Lithuania enjoyed a higher standard of living than many other republics of the Former Soviet Union (FSU). While Lithuania does not have abundant natural resources, it has inherited a highly skilled work force and a relatively well-developed infrastructure. 1.2 Agriculture is the second largest sector in the Lithuanian economy and has been one of the country's main sources of income, employment, and foreign exchange earnings'. By the end of 1994, agriculture accounted for nearly 23 % of the GDP, employed about 25 % of the labor force, and produced 24% of all exports. Traditionally the sector produced a surplus, mostly in livestock products which accounted for 67% of total agricultural output. Crop production, the bulk of which has been grain for the livestock industry, has averaged 30% of total agricultural output for most of the past decade. 1.3 By 1994 agricultural production declined by more than 35% when compared to 1987-89 average levels, while exports had declined even more, by roughly 50%. The livestock industry was particularly hard hit. Crop production had also declined; over 20% of arable land was left idle because of lack of inputs and working capital, uncertainty over property rights, and inadequate marketing support services. It is generally believed that the required reduction in agricultural production has been achieved as witnessed by the stabilized agricultural production levels of 1995. 1.4 Despite these recent problems, Lithuanian agriculture has the potential to become a reliable source of income and employment for the rural population. This will require structural adjustments in the sector induced through continuous policy reforms and rational investment strategies. Future production levels and patterns will have to be determined by market conditions and based on comparative advantages. Already, Lithuania has been quite successful in redirecting its agricultural exports to non-former Soviet Union (FSU) markets. There are also signs that investments are being made in the sector as farmers, with improving agricultural terms of trade, start to regain confidence. 1.5 The proposed Private Agriculture Development Project (PADP) would be the first Bank Group supported investment project for the agricultural sector in Lithuania. The PADP has been designed to promote the sector's transformation to a market-based system by removing some of the main constraints. In addition to investment credit, the project would provide technical assistance for strengthening rural financial intermediaries, and institutional and human skills conducive to the development of a private agricultural sector. Chapter I gives the general background information that is pertinent to the project, Chapter II evaluates the rural banking sector and the present constraints, Chapter III describes the project in detail, Chapter IV outlines implementation and management arrangements for the project, Chapter V analyzes benefits and risks of the project, and finally, Chapter VI summarizes agreements reached during negotiations and conditions for loan effectiveness. I For more information about the sector, please refer to Uthuanian Agriculture and Food Sector Review (report no. 13111-LT), issued on April 14, 1995, by the World Bank, Washington, DC.
 2 Chapter I B. AGRICULTURAL PERFORMANCE AND POLICY REFORMS 1.6 Macro stabilization. Since regaining independence in 1991, Lithuania has embarked on a reform program aimed at reorienting its economy away from a centrally planned system toward a market-based one. In that context, the Government of Lithuania (GOL) has made substantial progress in economic stabilization and structural reforms. Inflation declined from over 1,000% in 1992 to 410% in 1993. In 1994 the macro situation stabilized to the extent that inflation was down to 45%. The estimated inflation for 1995 is even lower, at around 30%. Since 1993 the country has had a fully convertible and stable currency, the Litas (LTL), which is pegged to the US dollar. Prices have been liberalized, a new trade regime is being developed, and the country has made progress in reorienting its trade. The share of non-FSU exports to total exports increased from 28% in 1992 to over 50% in 1994. Moreover, there has been significant progress in the privatization of banking institutions, small businesses, and agricultural land. 1.7 Agricultural Reforms to Date. The GOL is also committed to the transformation of the agricultural sector to compete in a market economy - a transition that includes agricultural policy reform, land reform, and privatization. The GOL's initial response during the post-Soviet era was to protect farmers; however such protectionist policies are now being progressively removed. To date the GOL has made considerable progress in a number of areas: (a) land restitution is at an advanced stage; (b) privatization of small-scale processing enterprises has been significant; (c) the GOL does not sets procurement quotas (except for a strategic food reserve) or controls consumer prices; (d) retail margin controls on foodstuffs were removed in early 1995; (e) import tariffs on foodstuffs, with few exceptions, were reduced to more moderate levels under the agreed Extended Fund Facility (EFF) program with the IMF; (f) bankruptcy laws have been enacted; and (g) competition laws and fair practice supervisory roles have been strengthened. 1.8 Reversal of Policy Reforms. In recent months, the Government of Lithuania has been subject to tremendous political pressure to take into greater account the social impact of the transition in the agricultural sector as well as the protectionism of the Western developed economies vis-a-vis imported agricultural goods. Due to increasing economic and social hardship, particularly for farmers and others in the rural sector, the Government has re-introduced minimum price supports for selected commodities and has slowed the elimination of subsidized credit. These recent moves are clearly a reversal of the previous liberal policy reforms achieved by the Government. Nevertheless, the new supports are limited in scope, and while they would delay the liberalization of the sector, they would not be able to reverse the structural reforms already being taking place in the sector. The minimum marginal price support scheme covers only a small number of products (milk, beef, pork, rapeseed, buckwheat and flax), and the LTL 137 million allocated for this in the 1995 budget was equivalent to less than 4% of the total Gross Value of Agricultural Output in that year. Furthermore, the recent trend in the market has led to market prices often exceeding the set minimum prices for most of the products, hence rendering the price support scheme ineffective and harmless. Additionally, contrary to the Government's announcement of gradual reduction, the budgetary allocation for subsidized credit has declined by more than 50% from LTL 110 million in 1994 to LTL 50 million in 1995. 1.9 Furthermore, in discussions with the Bank during the initial sector work and subsequent project preparation, the Government has re-iterated its commitment to policy reforms that would promote the growth of a market oriented and competitive agricultural sector. As an initial step toward meeting
 Background 3 that goal, the Government has started more direct support to farmers (e.g. providing incentives to improve the quality of their beef and milk through the provision of high quality breeding stocks, etc.). The Government has also stated in the Development Policy Letter (see Attachment 1 of this report) that it plans to phase out minimum price support and subsidized credit over a four year period ending in 1999. In addition, during project implementation, the Government has agreed to reduce the total agricultural subsidies each year by no less than 4% in real terms from the previous fiscal year's level. With the policy reforms achieved so far, and the continuous commitment by the Government, the distortions of the incentive systems in the sector are limited enough to justify Bank support. C. GOVERNMENT STRATEGY FOR RURAL DEVELOPMENT 1.10 Government's Objectives. The Government has declared that agriculture is a national priority because of the position it holds in social, cultural, and environmental affairs. Current opinion in the country suggests that Lithuania should support the most important agricultural products and exports; that natural resources and land should be protected and improved; that organic agriculture should be introduced; and that an optimal size structure of farms should be established based on market signals. 1.11 Surveys of farmers and Agricultural Companies (ACs), and the rural population2 have indicated that, in addition to declines in revenues from agricultural production, there are limited income earning opportunities for laid-off farmers and agricultural workers. The Government is keen to obtain technical assistance in the areas of retraining redundant workers and the re-engineering of existing production facilities. In particular, the Government is interested in: (a) stimulating the establishmnent of new rural businesses and group initiatives which create jobs; (b) stimulating the development of new rural income generating activities for families on small farms; (c) ensuring that the female population of rural areas benefits fromr the restructuring and development of the rural economies; (d) developing Lithuanian skills for long-term implementation of these goals; and (e) having support for the sector focus on development of the entire food delivery chain - from primary production, to processing, and to marketing and distribution. 1.12 New Roles of Government. The main development challenge facing Lithuania is the need to maintain a stable economy while accelerating and deepening the structural reform process to elicit a strong supply response in the private sector. Accordingly, the Government has recognized that during the transition, its role should change from the direct provision of goods and services towards indirect government guidance of the economy through legal, regulatory, and policy measures. Although imperfect, the legal and regulatory capacity is reasonable to foster private activities, and the Government continues to improve its supervisory capacity through various technical assistance and training program for civil servants. These changes would allow greater incentives and the opportunity to take advantage of the efficiency of the private sector, while reducing total government expenditure and easing overall fiscal pressures. Consistent with the general trend, Government expenditures on agriculture have fallen each year since 1991, primarily through a reduction in subsidies, and this trend is expected to continue. 2 The Survey was carried out by the Lithuanian Institute of Agrarian Economics in Autumn 1994 for the Social Program for Rural Development.
 4 Chapter I D. COMPARATIVE ADVANTAGES AND PROSPECTS FOR THE FUTURE 1.13 Comparative Advantages of the Agriculture Sector. The agriculture sector has good economic potential primarily because of its relatively favorable agro-climatic conditions, well established agricultural traditions, and a trained pool of farmers and technicians. The conditions are particularly well suited for production of grains, root crops, and livestock, and they are also suitable for the production of some fruits and vegetables. While the country traditionally has been a net exporter of livestock commodities to the rest of the FSU, crop and livestock yield potentials have not been realized, and there is much room for productivity gains. The food processing industry, once equipped with modem technology and more diversified product lines, can compete in international markets. With additional investment, the current high level of losses throughout the food production system from limited storage, handling, and transportation facilities can be significantly reduced. There is substantial potential to increase raw product yields and processing and distribution efficiency, which could increase the competitiveness of Lithuanian agriculture. 1.14 Efforts are now under way to improve economic conditions in rural areas by identifying and supporting alternative income and employment generating activities. Taking advantage of the relatively clean air and water in certain rural areas, small scale business opportunities such as eco- tourism, hunting, etc. are being explored. Handicrafts, especially textiles, woodworking, and log home building are being promoted as low-tech, natural resource based rural income earners. Regional governments are eager to receive technical assistance in identifying alternative employment possibilities and training in the skills necessary to pursue these opportunities. A pilot program, the Rural Employment Generation component devised under the proposed project, would support the selected districts by identifying alternative employment possibilities and providing training for new careers and business opportunities. The pilot program would be expanded to wider areas and be sustainable long after project funding has ceased (see paras. 3.2 and 3.23). 1.15 Challenges Ahead. Challenges remain during the transition period to restructure and revitalize the agriculture sector while removing the remaining constraints. The main challenges to address are: (a) the emergence of large numbers of newly created private farmers without productive assets and capital, the full range of inputs, or modern farming skills; (b) difficulty in creating and enforcing legal collateral; (c) the almost complete absence of medium- or long-term rural credit to the sector; (d) rural employment problems caused by the down-sizing of processing industries; (e) inefficient and under- utilized agro-industries with outdated technology and equipment; (e) slow privatization of large-scale agro- processing and service industries; and (f) the insufficient support services, including extension, research, marketing, and distribution. 1.16 To meet these challenges, the process of policy reform must continue to provide a nurturing environment for much-needed investment to revitalize the sector. This will facilitate the restructuring and rehabilitating of the sector based on market signals. Future lending for agriculture should be based on commercial and financial viability. Additionally, the reform program in agriculture should be consistent, and properly sequenced, with the macroeconomic reform framework and programs. A proposed Structural Adjustment Loan for Lithuania includes, among other things, a comprehensive agricultural policy reform package which would be coordinated and synchronized with other related intersectoral and macro-economic policy reform. In the interim, the proposed project would address some of these key constraints through its financial and technical assistance.
 CHAPTER II THE RURAL FINANCIAL SYSTEM A. THE BANKING SYSTEM 2.1 As is the case with most transitional economies, the financial sector in Lithuania is still weak. Since independence, three state-owned banks, 25 commercial banks, a development bank, and one representative office of a foreign bank have been established. The three state-owned banks, the Agricultural Bank, the State Savings Bank, and the State Commercial Bank, account for nearly 50% of total asset market share, however International Accounting Standards (IAS) audits of all three State Banks concluded that they all have inadequate capital structures and lack institutional capacity. Of the 25 private commercial banks created since independence, only about 15 were still functioning by mid-1995. While a significant informal financial sector had also developed post-independence, based mostly on local trading companies in search of profitable outlets for excess liquidity; their importance has recently declined sharply. 2.2 The Private Commercial Banks. Although about 15 commercial banks are still operating, this number is likely to be reduced in the coming years through consolidation, mergers, and liquidation. Most of the commercial banks had started out as the treasury arm of their state-owned enterprise founders. However, progress in enterprise privatization, and successful attempts at raising new capital have weakened those ties considerably. Some of the more active banks have already succeeded in acquiring credit lines from foreign sources. A few of the banks have participated in two EU-PHARE funded credit lines, each of which amounts to ECU 3 million and finances investments by small and medium-sized enterprises. Three of the more active banks have already been judged eligible to participate in the Enterprise and Financial Sector Assistance Project (EFSAP), recently approved by the Bank.' 2.3 During the last three years the larger private banks have been expanding their network of branches and many now have branch offices in the major towns of the country. Funding comes mainly from new private sector enterprises, and a large portion is denominated in foreign currency. While initially most of these banks limited their activities to short-term foreign currency loans and accounts in foreign correspondent banks, more recently banks have been expanding their lending activities to lending in domestic and foreign currency, mostly for short-term trading. International audits and portfolio reviews, coupled with the introduction by BOL of a loan classification and provisioning rule which became effective on April 1, 1994, indicate that most of the banks will have to raise additional capital and build up their loan loss provisions. Banks have started to respond to this challenge by cutting their dividend pay-outs and by increasing their efforts to increase their equity. B. FINANCING OF THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR Limited Credit to the Agricultural Sector 2.4 Due to lack of information, experience, and expertise in lending to agricultural activities, Lithuanian commercial banks are not extending credit to farmers and small-scale rural enterprises. High transaction costs of servicing small size farm loans, uncertainties surrounding collateral, titles, and a I Lithuania Enterprise and Financial Assistance Project, (Ln #8536 ) approved by the Board on April 13. 1995.

Banks are predominantly engaged in the financing of highly profitable short-term trading activities and there is very little long-term credit in the banking system as a whole, much less for lending to the agriculture sector. The current banking system has failed to respond to the phasing out of subsidized credit by the Government and the opportunities being opened up by newly emerging private farmers and private rural entrepreneurs. Yet, with more than 25% of the country's income being generated from agriculture, the sector presents a good choice for banks to diversify their lending and other banking activities. A program of targeted support which provides initial long-term credit to agriculture, accompanied by carefully designed technical assistance to beneficiaries, would act as a catalyst to overcome the above obstacles, and thus "open" the market potential of lending to previously excluded groups such as small-scale rural entrepreneurs and private farmers. Such directed support would demonstrate that agricultural lending can be profitable for banks if they are willing to acquire the necessary skills, and operate in the rural areas with an established client base. The project is designed to fill the gap by providing a catalytic force to develop a sound rural financing system. 2.5 Limited Support to Private Farmers. Official statistics show that the number of registered individual farm holdings exceeded 134,000 by the end of 1995, of which at least 30,000 are operating private farms and the remainder are leasing out their landholding to other farmers or ACs. Because of uneven and arbitrary granting of credits, the number of private farmers and ACs benefiting from the special short-term credits provided by the Government has been small. Furthermore, most of these private farmers and ACs have not had access to long-term conunercial credit. 2.6 With a near absence of long-term investment credit and pent-up demand on the part of newly established private farmers, demand for credit, particularly for long-term investment credit, is likely to be substantial. Agriculture traditionally has been an important contributor to the national economy and with a continuously increasing number of registered private farms, there would be an adequate client basis for the proposed US $30 million credit line. With estimated average loan sizes of LTL 20,000 for working capital and around LTL 200,000 to LTL 400,000 for long-term investment, the maximum number of clients to be served under the proposed project would be around 2,000 to 2,500. The Farm Survey (see para 3.31 and Annex 3) has also confirmed that the emerging private farmers have almost no access to investment credit to purchase appropriate equipment and fixed assets and to finance the start-up and development of their farming enterprise. 2.7 Subsidized Credit. By the end of 1994, total institutional credit to agriculture, almost entirely in the form of short-term credit, was about LTL 500 million. Of this, about 25 % was channeled from Government sources through the ABL at highly concessionary terms (at annual interest rates of 5 % and 8%). The source of this subsidized credit was the Agriculture Support Fund (ASF) which was created in February 1994 by the Government. A part of the ASF was also allocated to various subsidy programs for producers and processors, including subsidies for bread bakeries. By August 1, 1995, the total outstanding balance of loans financed from the ASF amounted to about LTL 122 million. Due to its relatively small size which is declining even more, the actual impact of subsidized credit has been relatively small and limited. 2.8 Furthermore, the Government has recognized that subsidized credit cannot be sustained and is too costly to the econorny. Accordingly, the GOL has: (a) proposed and obtained the necessary Parliamentary approval for diverting LTL 70 million from the ASF for recapitalization of the ABL; (b) reduced the budgetary allocation for subsidized credit from LTL 110 million in 1994 to LTL 50 million

As a project conditionality, an agreement with the Government was reached during negotiations on the gradual reduction of overall agricultural subsidies. This agreement provides that during Project implementation, the total amount of subsidies, including credit subsidies, to the agricultural sector would be reduced annually by no less than 4% in real terms from the previous fiscal year's level. The Agricultural Bank of Lithuania 2.9 The Agricultural Bank of Lithuania (ABL) has been the sole source of agricultural credit in Lithuania. ABL specializes in providing banking services to the agricultural sector although it is a universal bank authorized to serve all other sectors of the economy. In October, 1993, the bank formally became a joint stock company with a capital of LTL 20 million and 49% private ownership (with about 10% of the share capital held by a large number of ABL employees). The ABL has a network of 46 branches throughout the country, with a total staff of approximately 2,300 that serves about 215,000 clients. At the end of 1993, a portfolio review and audit in accordance with IAS revealed that, taking into account required provisions for its non-performing loans, the bank was insolvent as of December 31, 1993. The audit also pointed to deficiencies and weaknesses in the bank's credit policies, procedures, accounting, and internal control systems. 2.10 Positive Developments within ABL. Since its first IAS audit of 1993, the situation of the ABL has improved substantially. First, the senior management of ABL was changed during 1994. The new management is receptive to outside support and welcomes the restructuring and commercialization of the ABL with the ultimate goal of privatization. The IAS Audit for 1994 showed that ABL's capital position had improved considerably, and it had a net income of over LTL 68 million after taxes. The ABL had extended LTL 827 million (US $207 million) in loans, of which about 60% was for the agricultural sector, and approximately one third of this (LTL 158 million, or US $40 million equivalent) was to farmers. Its liabilities consisted of deposits, partly from its client borrowers - ACs, agro- processing enterprises, and private farmers. Bank of Lithuania (BOL) refinancing and special Government funding formed an important source of the ABL's loanable funds. Annex 4 provides additional information on the Agricultural Bank together with its audited financial statements for 1994. 2.11 The Government Commitment to ABL Restructuring. Further positive developments have occurred in ABL during 1995. The Government recognized that the ABL, with its extensive branch network and staff, was likely to be the main channel for rural credit and initiated measures to strengthen the ABL both financially and operationally: (a) the GOL has declared its commitment to discontinue the channeling of political loans through the ABL, thus separating the previous fiscal agency role from the ABL's commercial lending activities. In the interim, when acting as a fiscal agent for GOL, the ABL shall not bear the lending risk; (b) the GOL has agreed to take over bad loans which were the result of politically directed lending from the ABL's portfolio and to assist the ABL in its financial restructuring effort; and (c) the GOL has committed to inject new share capital which would allow ABL to fully restore its capital base and move towards becoming a viable commercial bank. The Government's proposal to recapitalize the ABL by diverting funds from the main source of subsidies, the Agricultural Support Fund, has been approved by Parliament. This would increase the ABL capital without additional budgetary pressures and at the same time reduce direct subsidies for agriculture.

In the interim, the Government would ensure full autonomy for the ABL in loan approval. The Government, in collaboration with the Council and Board of the ABL, will prepare a detailed privatization plan with a definite time-schedule during the first phase of the ABL twinning project. In order for the ABL to function as a commercial bank, it will require substantial institutional strengthening to improve both its management and operations. The proposed project would provide an opportunity to discontinue the past non- commercial practices of the ABL and transform it into a true commercial bank through comprehensive institutional development support along with a commercial credit line. An overall Institutional Development Program (IDP) through a two year twinning arrangement with an experienced foreign bank is being prepared. TA activities, supported by a team of long-term consultants and financed by EU- PHARE, for strengthening and improving credit management in ABL and other PFIs, have already been in place since fall 1995, and the new operational guidelines relating to credit operations would become effective before starting disbursements of the proposed Loan. The management of ABL is fully committed to implementing a wide-ranging institutional development program, with the assistance of foreign experts. TA modules with quarterly schedules, Terms of Reference (TOR), and indicators to monitor progress of the Institutional Development Program were prepared by the Bank and agreed with ABL and the Government (see para. 3.15 and Annex 5 for full details). C. STRENGTHENING RURAL FINANCIAL INTERMEDIATION 2.14 In order to identify potential financial intermediaries to address rural credit needs, particularly the needs of small-scale farmers and rural entrepreneurs and to determine which financial institutions would be most able to absorb the necessary TA for eventual financial intermediation under the proposed PADP, a survey of banks was carried out. The survey canvassed 11 banks, eight leading commercial banks and three State banks. The results showed: (a) All the private commercial banks expressed interest in participating in projects lending to agro- processing and agro-services enterprises; however commercial banks had reservations in regard to lending to the farming community, private individual farmers, and ACs. Only one commercial bank showed an interest in lending directly to farmers, and then only if they were linked to processing enterprises. (b) All three state banks, and the ABL in particular, expressed interest in lending to farmers, processors, and service enterprises. The results of the 1993 audit of the three state banks showed that they would require financial restructuring and major institutional improvements and strengthening before they could qualify to participate in Bank operations. 2.15 The PADP would mitigate the perceived risks in agricultural lending by providing necessary technical and financial assistance to a small number of major commercial banks willing to serve the agricultural sector. TA to improve the collateral basis through intensification of land titling, training of loan officers specifically in lending to agriculture, and strengthening institutional capabilities of banks
 The Rural Financial System 9 for improved efficiency and risk management would be provided. In addition, TA to strengthen extension and marketing services and other related activities would enhance productivities and profitability of agricultural investment. Consequently, it is expected that an increasing number of commercial banks would gradually become interested in lending to agriculture as their skills in this area improve, their understanding of sector dynamics grows, and as they are given access to external long-term financing. 2.16 Already one of the major private commercial banks which has satisfied the eligibility criteria for participation in the proposed PADP (para. 3.13), has expressed a strong interest in diversifying its lending operations to farmers, as well as processors, through participation in the PADP. Increased interest in lending to farmers illustrates that quick and large returns from financing short-term trading is declining and that banks seeking to stabilize their loan portfolio must diversify their lending. 2.17 It is recognized that the PADP cannot rely solely on one eligible bank. Other banks which satisfy the eligibility criteria would be encouraged to participate both in the credit line and the institutional strengthening program to improve their credit management system. The support for the ABL, mentioned in the previous section, would also provide a wide ranging institutional development program to transform the ABL into an efficiently operating commercial bank with full autonomy. The current status of the ABL's compliance with the eligibility criteria is summarized in Annex 4. BENEFITS AND JUSTIFICATIONS 5.1 The project would contribute toward the creation of a sound rural financing system while complementing the Bank's on-going effort in banking sector reforms. The project would, through continuous policy dialogue and a wide range of technical assistance activities, alleviate key policy and institutional constraints that hamper the adjustments necessary for complete transition to a market economy. The credit line provided under the project would finance private economic activity and stimulate a supply response. Improved productivity and environmental management of primary and processing enterprises are another consequence of the project, together with increased competitiveness and enhanced marketability of Lithuanian products. Through a pilot program, the project would, at a grass-roots level, provide support for identification of alternative income opportunities and the corresponding training to pursue those opportunities. Such efforts would help combat the growing rural poverty and unemployment which disproportionately affects women. After a successful pilot period, this program would be expanded nation-wide. Other benefits include improvements in marketing capacity, linkage between research and extension, and training in business and management skills. B. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL EVALUATIONS 5.2 Consistency with the CAS. The proposed project is consistent with the Bank's overall priorities for private and financial sector development strategies outlined in the CAS and as agreed with the Lithuanian Government. Key sectoral issues and development strategies were identified during the Bank's Agriculture and Food Sector Review', and have been incorporated in the project design. 5.3 Adeguate Polio Environment. Notwithstanding the remaining areas of required policy reforms, the Government of Lithuania has made considerable progress both on macro-economic and sector policy fronts (see Chapter 1 for more details) which in turn provides an adequate policy environment to facilitate development of private activities in rural areas. 5.4 Alternative Options during the Transition Period. Perceptions of high risk in lending to agriculture, inadequate institutional and human resources, and the remaining legacy of past interventionist policies have prevented farmers and small-scale entrepreneurs from gaining access to commercial long- term credit. A lack of lending skills and suitable long-term funds in Lithuanian banks has also aggravated the situation. The project would provide interim measures to overcome these transitional constraints by providing intensive institutional and human resource development TA support, in addition to long-term credits and permanent working capital.  Lithuania Private Agriculture Development Project 41 LITHUANIA Private Agricultural Development Project ANNEX 2: Land Reform and Privatization Background 1. The current land reform program in Lithuania has its roots in 1989 when it became permissible for individual farmers to lease up to 50 ha of agricultural land on favorable terms. In 1991 a new land reform law was passed the prime objective of which was (a) to restore land and real property rights to those who had owned land prior to 1940 and to their heirs; and (b) to privatize land that had been held by collective farms. The land laws were further amended in 1993 and 1994 in the light of experience with land restitution. A new draft law on land registration is now (1995) in preparation. A law on mortgaging land was passed in 1992, but has not yet been implemented. A law governing physical planning and development control has been drafted. 2. The objective of the land reform program is to reestablish land markets and to put the ownership of much of the land in Lithuania into private hands. Eight categories of land and property have been recognized: -- Public Buildings that will remain in public ownership. - Private buildings in urban and village areas. - Forest land that will remain in public ownership. - Farm and forest land that is subject to restitution or allocation and is mainly in plots of between 8 and 10 ha. - Land held in leasehold from the state. - Communal land around villages awaiting distribution in 2-3 ha plots. -- Allotments owned by garden societies. - Garden plots with summer houses. 3. Applications for land restitution or allocation are lodged at the local district or municipal office. A preliminary decision on the validity of the application is made by the local subdistrict agrarian reform board. If the application is in order, instructions are sent to field surveyors to carry out a preliminary survey and mark out the area affected. The documents are then sent to the District Agrarian Reform Board for approval. It may take anything from one month to a year before a decision is made. If the application is accepted, the district land surveying board will carry out a preliminary registration, and will enter the details in the District Office. The applicant must then arrange for a precise geodetic survey of the property before a final certificate of ownership can be issued. 4. The preliminary recording of title to summer houses with small gardens is expected to be completed early in 1996 since estimates indicate that the majority have already been completed. The conversion of these preliminary certificates of ownership into fully registered titles also depends on the completion of geodetic surveys for which additional payment will be required. Many landowners appear unwilling to incur this extra expenditure.

The sample consisted of 300 private farms and 50 Agricultural Companies (ACs). Initially it was intended that random sampling techniques would be used to select the 300 private farms. However, the absence of a consistent sampling frame precluded this and, consequently, LAAS advisors attempted to use quasi-random techniques to select farmers within their regions while trying to ensure that at least one third of respondents were not LAAS clients. The heterogeneity of the ACs and the smaller sample size resulted in the adoption of a purposeful sampling technique for these farms, the intention being to have broad coverage of the geographic, productive, and financial diversity of the ACs. 20. The survey cannot therefore be regarded as fully representative of farming in Lithuania. Indeed, the sample appears to contain a higher proportion of the larger private farms than in the population. The survey does, however, give a strong indication of the structure and trends within Lithuanian farming. Agricultural Company (AC) Farm Systems 21. ACs have certainly undergone major change since formation in 1992, losing roughly a fifth of their land and employees (though over 70 percent lease land from private individuals ). However, most are still managed by the old collective leadership with little change in management structure other than a reduction in the number of specialists. The ownership of ACs is dominated by pensioners (52 percent of shares) and to a lesser extent workers (38 percent). This has contributed to overstaffing (only 8.4 hectares per employee), especially in the crop and machinery areas, despite large-scale mechanization. 22. Given the correct incentives, there is ample room for technical improvement on ACs. In general, ACs have adopted mixed farming systems with equal areas of crops and grass. Barley dominates cropping and is largely consumed on-farm, though most ACs also try to grow cash crops (25 percent grow oilseed rape). Dairy cows and their progeny dominate livestock systems, and pigs are also found on most units. However, stocking rates and crop and stock yields are roughly half of Western European rates, and the levels of home-grown and purchased concentrate feed consumption are excessive. Most ACs rely heavily on traditional enterprises with very few raising off-farm income. The exception is machinery services, though this contributes little to total income. 23. Some ACs were found to be generating very large cash surpluses. There was not, however, a strong correlation between the size of the net cashflow with the farm enterprises pursued although those with wheat, pig, sugar beet and unusual (e.g. fur) enterprises tended to have larger positive cashflows. Some ACs where traditional cattle and milk enterprises dominate also had large positive cashflows. In contrast, other ACs had large negative net trading cashflows. These ACs tended to have high fixed costs, especially for repairs and contracting. The key determinant between those ACs with positive and negative net trading cashflows would seem to be the managerial ability.

 Lithuania Private Agriculture Development Project 77 LITHUANIA Private Agricultural Development Project ANNEX 6: Rural Business Development Component (RBC) The Need 1. The changing economic environment in Lithuania has resulted in significant changes in rural employment structures. As larger agricultural entities privatize and increase their efficiency, excess labor has been forced to seek new employment. Similarly, the emerging private farming system has resulted in smaller family farms, which in some cases are too small to generate sufficient revenue to meet family expenses. Yet there are very few alternative sources of employment in rural areas. In a more mature economy, some of this growing rural un- and under-employment would be absorbed by emerging entrepreneurial business opportunities in providing agricultural services and product processing to the remaining, more efficient, agricultural producers. Other small business opportunities to take advantage of rural craft-making abilities, and other skills in the rural population would also arise. Yet this is not happening in Lithuania because the expertise, support systems, and business development services are not yet in place to nurture this process. 2. Experience shows that agencies providing business support can have great success in fostering indigenous enterprise and nurturing new businesses through the critical first few years. The skills required in such agencies extend far beyond the standard business consulting functions. First, such agencies must adopt a pro-active approach - if they do not, potential business opportunities are lost either through the inability of untrained individuals to express them clearly, or through the fear that they will not be taken seriously. Second, the agencies must have a sound ability to recognize potentially viable projects based upon incomplete information or conversely, to screen out business ideas that have little or no chance of success. Staff seconded from successful businesses are crucial in order to fulfill this role. Third, the agency must act as a facilitator, drawing together individuals with the appropriate skills to support the development of specific business proposals. Such individuals may include those with the skills required to judge market potential and technical feasibility, as well as those that can assist businesses in undertaking financial analyses and preparing marketing strategies. Since different business proposals would require different expertise, rarely would such an agency maintain all the skills in-house. Extensive contacts are therefore vital to the operation of the agency. 3. Because there are no organized structures in place to link up excess rural labor with potential rural business opportunities, an attempt was made to identify possible information and assistance sources for rural entrepreneurs and private farmers in the forn of a survey of Lithuanian agricultural and business consulting companies and services. The survey identified the following entities with the potential to eventually assist private farmers and rural entrepreneurs; the Lithuanian Agricultural Advisory Service (LAAS), the Innovation Center at the Lithuanian Agricultural Academy, 15 small companies, several large international consulting companies, and the European Union (EU)- supported Business Centers. A thorough analysis of the services provided by these organizations revealed that major gaps exist in the provision of consulting services to private farmers, small-scale agricultural service and supply organizations, and agro-processors.

The Rationale for a Rural Business Development Center 5. The Rural Business Development Center (RBC) was conceived as a key link in developing rural entrepreneurship, orienting the existing private business consulting sector towards rural business consulting, and identifying business opportunities for the un- and under-employed rural population. The RBC is envisioned as a catalyst in directing existing private structures, and the creation of new private enterprises, to absorb excess rural labor, while at the same time directing that labor into providing services needed by the rural population. The RBC would not supplant or compete with existing public or private structures addressing rural employment opportunities, but rather complement these existing efforts by serving as conduit to existing services so that they can better fulfill their mandates. As a nexus for rural business development, the RBC would closely interact with public and private entities in the following manner: 6. Creation and Evaluation of Coherent Business Plans and Feasibility Studies. As the Participating Financial Intermediaries (PFIs) of the PADP would bear full lending risks of any loans they make, they can lend only on the basis of strict commercial criteria. Foremost among these criteria is the expected ability of proposed investment to generate sufficient revenue for entrepreneurs to meet interest and repayment obligations. But in order to convince the PFI loan officers and/or commnittees that proposed investments meet these criteria, entrepreneurs would need to demonstrate that their proposals are well conceived and based on technical feasibility, sound procurement practices, and fill a market need in the supply of goods or services demanded by consumers. The RBC would help potential borrowers articulate and create business plans which could meet PFI lending criteria. 7. Identification of Additional Business Development Resources. Once a potential business opportunity has been identified and adequate business planning and feasibility of implementation has been assured, the RBC would assist the client in identifying public and private resources which could help the client develop market strategies (information and research, product or service positioning) and is familiar with the client's local market. The RBC would maintain a list of "RBC approved" business development consulting firns which can help RBC clients at this stage. More sophisticated rural entrepreneurs or those with adequate financial resources could also use the RBC's referral service to find private sector assistance in maximizing their businesses' potential. 8. Overall, agriculture is an area where environmental improvements are and can be made with success and at relatively low costs. The break-up of large farms, and redistribution of land will increase the care and concern for land, and will end the monoculture and its reliance on intensive use of agro-chemicals. The increasing interest in agro-tourism also enhances the attention for environmentally acceptable agricultural practices. 2. The proposed operation is expected to have positive environmental effects through the promotion of improved land use practices, farming methods and agricultural product processing. The proposed project has been reviewed consistent with the requirements of the Lithuanian environmental assessment procedures (as explained in the Environmental Aspects annex of Lithuania Power Rehabilitation Project) and the provisions of Operational Directive 4.01 'Environmental Assessment', and placed in environmental screening category "B". 3. Developments in agriculture. The detrimental effects of the previous command economy are widely known, and not much different from that in other parts of the region. However, despite major efforts in drainage and intensification of agriculture, most of the landscape, with smaller woodlots and ponds, was left intact thereby enhancing water management. The present contraction of the agricultural sector has actually helped to reduced environmental problems associated with intensive agriculture. The amount of fallow land has increased (to an estimated 200,000 HA) thereby decreasing the risk of erosion and the need for pesticides. 4. Pesticide use has declined from 4 Kg/HA in 1989 to less than 1 Kg/HA in 1994, as most are beyond the purchasing power of cash strapped farmers. At present mainly the richer AC's use pesticides; most private farmers have replaced the use of herbicides with manual weeding for example. Main crops on which pesticides are used include rape, sugarbeets and flax. Most of the previous government incentives for pesticide use (subsidized pricing) have been terminated, except for a few rayons where local governments have implemented small schemes to promote pesticide use. Although the use of agricultural inputs is expected to rise, private farming, market economy, and better extension/information are expected to lead to a more judicious use than under the command economy. 5. Recent developments. Since 1993 the Government of Lithuania has taken measures to strengthen environmental management practice in all sectors, including agriculture. In 1994 it upgraded the Environmental Protection Department to the Ministry of Environmental Protection and is in the process of preparing a National Environmental Action Plan (NEAP), which includes, with support by EU- PHARE, the preparation of a new environmental law. It has also co-sponsored regional conferences on environmental issues in agricultures in countries in economic transition (with OECD) and management of agricultural run-off (with USEPA/World Bank). The government has developed its own laws and regulations concerning sustainable agricultural practices, including new guidelines on the use of pesticides by the Plant Protection Agency. Lithuania has also undertaken cooperative programs with Denmark for the management of obsolete agricultural chemicals and pesticides, Sweden in the management of
 88 Annex 8 agricultural run-off, and the USEPA in the management of polder agriculture. It has also initiated (with support of USEPA) a program of management of the environmentally vulnerable northern Karst zone, where both soil erosion and groundwater contamination are a major concern, leading the Government to recommend a limitation of agricultural activities in an area of 160,000 HA. 6. In order to respond to the increasing need for environmentally sustainable agricultural practices the Ministry of Agriculture has recently established a Committee for Environmental Issues. Among the first topics to be addressed is a comprehensive review of the implementation of the removal and destruction of obsolete pesticides (with the assistance of Denmark), and further review of the present list of approved pesticides. In this effort it is following international standards including use of the WHO classification. 7. The Ministry of Agriculture continues its support for farmer training and requires certification of pesticide users, but this program is increasingly hampered by the high cost, of protective clothing, and the lack of training material. Training is provided through either/or LAAS, Plant Protection, local Agricultural Schools. This year the Plant Protection Agency has sent its first staff member overseas for training in integrated pest management (IPM). Effect of the Proposed Project 8. One of the major objectives of the project is to establish a sound farm credit program with loan officers trained in all aspects of agricultural lending including (environmental) risk assessment. Project supported investments at the farm level and in the agro-processing industries are intended to: (a) increase the efficiency of the use of agricultural inputs (fuel, fertilizers, pesticides); (b) decrease soil erosion by better land use practices; (c) increase energy efficiency through the introduction of new equipment; and (d) reduce air pollution through the phasing out of coal fired heat and boiler units. The proposed project would support the strengthening of Lithuanian capacities in environmentally sound approaches to agriculture through support for the strengthening of agricultural extension services, provision of advisory services to agro-processing industries and training of personnel from cooperating financial institutions in the environmental review methods. 9. Potential impacts associated with proposed small scale projects would be mitigated through the adoption and active implementation of environmental screening procedures appropriate for intermediate lending operations by cooperating financial institutions and through implementation of applicable environmental procedures by national, regional and local entities charged with environmental assessment. Monitoring of the environmental aspects of relatively small investment would be conducted principally by regional offices and local offices complemented by periodic supervision by environmental staff from the Bank's regional office. Environmental Management 10. An environmental review was prepared for the proposed Project consistent with the requirements of Lithuania environmental assessment legislation and the provisions of World Bank Operational Directive 4.01, "Environmental Assessment" and placed in environmental screening category "b". The proposed project is expected to result in environmental benefits by supporting a series of small scale improvements in a wide range of agricultural practices as recommended by the extension service.

The project would include provisions of environmental review by Lithuanian environmental authorities of proposed investments. Where applicable investments supported under the proposed project would require issuance of permits consistent with the applicable Lithuanian land use and environmental procedures (these procedures are to be listed in the new Environmental Law; till that time the decrees listed in par. 13 apply. Present environmental regulations recognize three layers of authority that regulate and monitor environmental standards: (a) At the ground level is the rayon or municipal government. Most small projects (e.g. local construction etc.) need only local approval. To obtain such approval the project is reviewed by a local committee consisting of the Environmental Affairs specialist in the rayon, the rayon Hygienist and, if pesticides are involved, a local representative of the State Plant Protection Agency. However, the ability of the bureaucracy to implement varies. The city of Vilnius, for example, has created and environmental agency, but in some of the rural rayon the monitoring and survey and done by rayon architects or others not directly trained in environmental assessment. Progress is being made in training. (b) The Ministry of the Environment has ten regional offices. These offices supervise, among others, the rayon level implementation, and specifically handle the environmental assessment of larger regional projects and issues. Examples are especially construction investments and investments which may create new waste water. (c) Environmental assessment of still larger issues and projects (large scale industrial projects, pipelines) is handled by the relevant office in the central Ministry of the Enviromnent. 12. The responsibility for environmental monitoring of the relatively small investments (less than 1 million litas) made under the project will mainly be at the local (rayon) governments. Few, if any, investments or special cases are envisaged to need review by regional offices. Local regulations require submission of simple request which includes a one-page form dealing with the use of raw materials and the production, storage and management of waste, and, where applicable, the description of the possible physical and biological pollutants created by the investment and the remedial counter measures taken. With respect to agriculture, these regulations mainly affect construction of dwelling, public building, animal production building or facilities, greenhouses except when heated by gas generators) storage facilities of crops as well as fuel, well drilling, animal burial sites, power lines and some others. 13. Investments in or near protected areas will require special review in the regional offices of the Ministry of the Environment. Such special reviews include those made in the "intensive karst zone" targeted by the Government for Ground Water Protection and Sustainable Agricultural Development (Birzai and Pasvalys rayon). 14. The basic procedures for screening of small scale investments are well established and documented in recent decrees and regulations (decree 87 of 12/17/90; regulations # 153-93 and decree 154-60 of 8131/93). These rules are aimed are mainly aimed at larger investments, but will be used to ascertain consideration of proper environmental standards preservation of the top soil, solid and liquid waste management, proper management of drainage and run-off, as well as of assessment and management of the impact of agricultural production related investments such as workshops, storage etc. on groundwater quality, on trees, shrubs and plant life, and on wildlife and fish. These rules are to ascertain proper construction standards. All infrastructure investment lending under the project would require permits.

The relatively poor soils and the cool climate narrow the opportunities of farms in their selection of product mix and farming system. The seasons are short, and limited by often wet springs and autumns, which may complicate respectively planting and harvesting. However, there are good opportunities for root crops, forage, and livestock production. These production systems would greatly benefit from improvement in the availability of inputs, equipment, improvements in energy efficiency and overall management. The marketing opportunities of quality products is, in the long term, good with nearby urban markets such as Vilnius and Kaunas and beyond larger population centers in Kaliningrad, Russia, Belarus, and Poland. II. One of the project objective is to assist farmers in the transition from , mainly, large-scale collective farning to smaller-scale family farming or, in some cases, farming cooperatives. Apart from the change in fanming system, it is also expected that the product mix of farms is going to change and probably broaden from the previously mandated cereal production and intensive livestock. In this rapidly changing sector, farm lending is likely to concentrate initially on seasonal inputs (seeds, fuel, agro- chemicals, fertilizer and small equipment) and limited investments in equipment, buildings, livestock and storage facilities. Larger farms may invest also in small scale processing. III. Crop/livestock budaets. The attached crop and livestock budgets demonstrate the difference in outlook of a selected number of crops under present and improved conditions. The examples are derived from the crop budgets developed by the Lithuanian Agricultural Advisory Service, in its effort to assist Lithuanian farmers to make more rational decisions on crop mix and future investments. These budgets are tentative, however, as crop prices are still volatile. Potatoes prices, for example, were high in early 1995 due to the drought in 1994 (as such somewhat lower prices were used in the models). Pig prices are also high, a trend common throughout the region during 1994-95. Cereal prices, on the other hand appear to have reached a more stable level, and may better reflex future price levels. Most of the selected crops, except flax and milk, are not subsidized and reflect real market prices. IV. Whole farm models Whole farm models are presented for two typical private farms, one which represents the 89ers and one which represents restitution farms. It should, however, be noted that major changes in farm system are likely during the course of the Project so that these farm models are merely indicative. For instance, the management of grassland is likely to substantially improve through the adoption of improved temporary leys using improved seed and the adoption of silage based forage systems. The increased efficiency of grassland use will allow improved management of livestock increasing the quality of output and stocking densities. In addition, good opportunities exist for some private farmers to produce vegetables for urban markets which would generate high margins. V. Example Cashflows for a family farm and an agricultural company (Bendrove) were derived from the World Bank supported Farm Survey Report and somewhat modified. They demonstrate the present weakness, especially of the agricultural company, where high overhead costs severely depress cash flow. Improvement in management and in agronomic practices, to be stimulated through LAAS
 94 Annex 10 advice, as well as investments in better inputs, and more efficient production (for example through more energy efficient equipment use) may help these farms to improve their performance. The cash flow of private farmers appear somewhat better, but here also, major improvements are possible through better product choices and greater efficiency. VI. Storage. Apart from investments on the production side, major improvements are expected to be made through investment in better storage, transport, and marketing. The impact of improved storage is difficult to determine but is probably significant through: (a) reduction in losses in the field as well as in storage; (b) increased farm flexibility during harvest time (less weather dependent); and (c) increased flexibility in marketing. Table 4 makes an effort to estimate some of the benefits of better storage, concentrating on reduced losses, and higher quality. Estimates of the reduction in these losses are made, on a per ton basis. These improvements are then aggregated for a total benefit for an average farm. A simple rate of return is calculated. The latter are somewhat low, as the chosen farm size is rather small. There is a scale element in these investments, and the benefits are likely to be higher in larger farms (the alternative of renting out storage space is well possible, but was not considered in this simple models).

 LITHUANIA PRIVATE AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT PROJECT PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION PLAN I. THE PROJECT A. Introduction 1. This Project Implementation Plan was prepared by the Ministry of Agriculture with the support of the Policy and Human Resource Development (PHRD) Team during appraisal and will be agreed upon in accordance with the procedures set out in the OP/BP/GB 10.00. The complete design is presented as an overview in Chart 1 below. B. Project Scope and Objectives 2. The Private Agricultural Development Project (The Project) would increase the availability of commercial credit to private farmers, privatised state or collective farms (known as Agricultural Companies), agricultural and food processors, agro-service companies and rural enterprises, and support the market orientation of the agricultural, food, and rural sectors with appropriate Technical Assistance in accordance with the following objectives: * to strengthen and restructure rural credit delivery systems; * to increase the availability of finance for the upgrading of technology and production facilities; * to foster the development of private farms and promote the emergence of private small and medium enterprises in rural areas; * to provide seed money, retraining, and advice for the development of opportunities for income and employment generation in rural areas and the diversification of farm businesses; * to help establish land markets and tradeable private land ownership rights and increase access to credit by establishing legally binding collateral; * to improve the efficiency with which markets indicate consumers wants and needs through improving the institutional framework of markets (including improved price dissemination); * to improve the business management skills and marketing ability of farmers and entrepreneurs so that they can identify, evaluate, and pursue business development opportunities which improve productivity and the competativeness of Lithuanian products in domestic and export markets; and thereby reduce poverty.
 112 Project Implementation Plan C. Project Description 3. Both multilateral and bilateral donors have supported the development of the Lithuanian agricultural and food sector which is the second largest in the Lithuanian economy. This support has assisted Lithuania in its transformation of the agricultural and food economies to a system where resources are allocated by markets according to the prices that are the result of consumers' purchasing behaviour. However, to date much of the Technical Assistance has been directed towards the investment in physical capital which was required to promote land reform, establish an extension organisation, and provide agricultural machinery and vehicles. The Agricultural and Food Sector Review indicated that despite this assistance there still exist some important constraints to the development of a competitive market based food distribution chain to the detriment of farmers and consumers alike. 4. A competitive market economy requires a large number of buyers and sellers, the wide availability of information (especially market information), and access to capital. Since these conditions are not currently satisfied in Lithuania the proposed Project will be implemented as an Investment Project the main components of which will be: Long term credit for on- and off-farm investments, seasonal credits for farm inputs and initial working capital for processors; Institutional and human resource development through Technical Assistance to improve the capacity of those involved in the agricultural and food sectors to respond to market signals through the development of agricultural market and technical information sources, and business and technical skills as well as for the development of the land market in Lithuania. 5. Credit Component. The lack of available credit is hindering the establishment of new firms or the development of existing firms undertaking agricultural input and service supply (including machinery service contractors), small and medium sized agro processing, and market intermediaries such as wholesalers, traders and distributors. This is limiting competition particularly in the agro- processing sector which is highly oligopolistic. This is an important reason for the poor prices that farmers receive and the substantial delays before they are paid. The lack of credit is also hindering the development of the large number of new private farmers and the Agricultural Companies which were created from the privatised non-land assets of the former State and Collective farms. Consequently, the primary agricultural producers are having difficulty developing their production and competing with the quality of imported products. The results of the farm survey conducted by the Lithuanian Agricultural Advisory Service, the Association of Agricultural Companies and the Lithuanian Institute of Agrarian Economics with the assistance of the PHRD Team, confirmed that both private farmers and Agricultural Companies (the privatised former state and collective farms) have a large demand for long term credit. The farm survey also indicated that currently they lack such credit. Additionally there is a need to develop alternative employment opportunities in rural areas which will help to alleviate both the
 Project Implementation Plan 113 rising unemployment that results from farm and enterprise restructuring as well as the low incomes generated by the large number of small farms. 6. Consequently, in order to increase the availability of long term credit to private farms, Agricultural Companies, farm service companies, small and medium sized agro-processors, and rural enterprises a $30 million Line-of-Credit will be extended to Lithuania. The World Bank will provide the loan to the Government of Lithuania (GOL) in the form of a Single Currency Loan at the Banks' standard variable interest rate which is adjusted every six months. The loan will be repaid according to terms and conditions agreed at negotiations. 7. The credit will be channelled to sub-borrowers through participating financial intermediaries (PFIs) which will draw upon the Line-of-Credit with the Bank of Lithuania (BOL) acting as an APEX agency on behalf of the Ministry of Finance. For each eligible sub-loan that they make, PFIs will be able to draw upon the Line-of-Credit in either US$ or Litas dependant upon the currency within which the sub-loan is denominated. Where PFIs draw upon the Line-of-Credit in US$ the BOL shall add to the interest rate changed by the World Bank , a margin to cover administration costs and repayment risks. Where the PFIs draw upon the Line-of-Credit in Litas, BOL shall on lend at a variable market determined interest rate which shall be set in relation to the BOL's refinancing or rediscount rate. 8. It is expected that the PFIs shall be private commercial banks' which satisfy World Bank eligibility criteria and the Agricultural Bank of Lithuanian (ABL) once it meets the eligibility criteria applied by the World Bank. The PFIs will bear the full credit risks of the sub-projects financed from the Line-of-Credit. 9. Potential sub-borrowers will apply to a PFI for a sub-loan. Sub-loans may be denominated either in US$, in which case the sub-borrower bears the exchange rate risk, or in Litas, in which case the government will bear the exchange rate risk. The interest rates charged by PFIs on sub- loans in US$ or Litas shall be variable and determined by PFIs according to their risk assessment of the sub-project, their lending costs and the costs of funds on lent by the Apex Unit. Interest rates shall be market determined and positive in real terms. Applications will be assessed by each PFI on the basis of the commercial viability of the proposed sub-project. Applicants will need to demonstrate such viability by undertaking feasibility studies which will detail the technical, economic, financial and environmental soundness of the sub-project. In order to promote small investment projects, and thereby improve competition in the sector, there will be a limit of US$250 thousand on the total size of sub-loans that can be made under the Project to a single borrower. Since the proposed Bank loan is intended to assist the development of private enterprise in the agricultural, food and rural sectors there will be an additional restriction that companies will only be eligible for a loan under this credit line if there is a least 51 % private ownership of the company. All activities financed under the Line-of-Credit would be required to comply with GOL environmental standards.
