Institutional and Human Resource Development Component. The development of human capital is now a priority for the further development of the whole food distribution chain and for the promotion of employment in rural areas. This component would therefore consist of Technical Assistance to assist in the following areas: Marketing. Currently within Lithuania agricultural and food production is not determined according to the wants and need of consumers as expressed through market signals or market research. There are a variety of reasons for this. Paramount is the lack of market institutions for the trading of agricultural inputs and outputs which result in primary agricultural producers having a lack of choice as to purchased inputs and a lack of buyers for their output. This limits competition amongst input suppliers and agro-processors so that primary producers pay higher input prices and receive lower output prices than otherwise would be the case. This problem is compounded by private farmers' lack of adequate storage and transportation facilities which further impedes their inter-temporal and spatial marketing decisions. A lack of experience of market behaviour over time and between locations together with a lack of market information also hinders such decision making. In addition to these problems related to the under development of market institutions, farmers also face a lack of demand for their output. A main reason for this is that the output of many Lithuanian agro-processors does not satisfy the wants or needs of consumers in the domestic or export markets. There are a variety of reasons for this including a lack of trained marketing professionals and the lack of an effective trade promotion agency. Consequently the following Technical Assistance programmes shall be undertaken to alleviate these problems: Farm Level Marketing - The Development of Marketing Institutions: To assist the creation of a decentralised market economy through the development of Lithuanian experience in the establishment and operation of agricultural market institutions. Agricultural Market Education: To assist participants in the agricultural markets develop their experience of the determinants of market prices including the effects of product quality and location, and the causes of price movements in the short, medium and longer terms. Food Marketing Training Courses: To improve the marketing abilities of those involved in the production and sale of processed agricultural products.
 Project Implementation Plan 115 Trade Information Development: To assist the Agricultural Trade Agency, to be established by the Ministry of Agriculture, create a service for the collection, processing, storage and dissemination of trade data. Product Workshops: To improve the export performance of the agricultural, food and fishery sectors of the Lithuanian economy. Export Promotion: To assist the development of Lithuanian skills in the production of export promotional material and the undertaking of an international trade mission. Business Skill Development. The ability for entrepreneurs and business consultants to prepare rational business plans and studies of the feasibility of investments is vital for the success of the credit component of the project. Although Lithuanian capability in these areas is developing there is a need for the training of private farmers and managers of Agricultural Companies who currently tend to lack the business skills and experience required to plan sound investments and effectively manage their enterprises. Private farmers require simple training to understand the profitability, cashflow and capital position of their businesses as a priority and subsequent training in the judgement of project feasibility. The managers of Agricultural Companies require training in methods to evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of their businesses and in the skills to implement the changes required. Thus the following Technical Assistance programmes will be undertaken: Training Private Farmers in Understanding and Judging Feasibility: To assist Lithuanian institutions develop and deliver training courses for private farmers on the concept and techniques required to develop feasible investment projects. Agricultural Company Management Training: To strengthen and develop the managerial capacity of the Agricultural Companies and thereby aid the process of their transformation. Extension System Development. In 1993 the Lithuanian Agricultural Advisory Service (LAAS) was established and in a short space of time this organisation has made great progress in providing extension services to private farmers. The establishment of the organisation was greatly assisted by EU-PHARE which provided much of the physical investment required (vehicles, technical equipment, computers, office equipment and supplies, etc.). LAAS has also received technical assistance and training from a variety of countries including Denmark and Sweden and organisations such as VOCA. Currently LAAS is receiving Technical Assistance funded by EU-PHARE and the British Government's Know How Fund. These technical assistance programmes are providing training for farm advisors and financing an experienced co-director to assist the director of LAAS with strategic planning and to co- ordinate the training input. Although the advisory service is developing well, other aspects of the farm extension system remain under developed and there is a need to increase the flow of information from research and education organisations and the Ministry of Agriculture to the advisory service and farmers.
 116 Project Implementation Plan The Ministry of Agriculture is a key organisation within the overall extension system since it has the roles of fostering competitive agricultural and food sectors through its policy making role and through the production and dissemination of information. In order to be able to increase the flow of information it is necessary that appropriate information collection systems are developed. Currently, the rapid privatisation of the farm sector has resulted in a lack of reliable information since the information systems collected data from the former state and collective farms (the non-land assets of which have been privatised into "Agricultural Companies") rather than private farms. Consequently the following Technical Assistance programmes shall be undertaken: Flexible Extension System Development: To further the development of the whole extension system by facilitating the two-way flow of information through the system so that it meets the need of farmers. Ministry of Agriculture Management Training: To facilitate the adaptation of the Ministry of Agriculture and related institutions to their new role of fostering a competitive market based economy. The Further Development of the Census of Farm Businesses: To reduce the cost of undertaking the Institute of Statistic's census of farm businesses so that it may be undertaken on an annual basis. The Development of a Survey of Private Farm Accounts: To implement a survey of farm accounts that is broadly compatible with similar surveys used in market based economies. Survey of Farmer Opinion: To provide information on the opinions and perceptions of farmers and thereby aid the monitoring and evaluation of the Private Agricultural Development Project. Rural Employment Generation. The privatisation of the farm sector through the restitution of land and the privatisation of the non-land assets of the state and collective farms into Agricultural Companies will inevitably result in: the creation of a large number of small farms which are of insufficient size to generate sufficient income to satisfy all the expenditure needs of a family; and an increase in visible unemployment as the Agricultural Companies restructure and shed the labour which currently constitutes hidden unemployment. Therefore, increasingly there will be a need for members of families operating small farms to undertake alternative income generating activities, on- or off-farm, in addition to farming. Likewise, in order to avoid rural depopulation, there will be a need to assist rural communities develop new job opportunities. It has been noted by the Women Farmers' Union that within Lithuania in many cases it is females on farms that are attempting to undertake alternative activities. Thus in order that the assistance meets the identified needs in Lithuania and to avoid the female rural population being economically disenfranchised by the restructuring and development process a large part of the assistance shall be targeted at the needs of the female rural population. A
 Project Implementation Plan 117 Technical Assistance programme shall be undertaken to: stimulate the development of alternative rural employment opportunities by raising the awareness of the rural population to alternative opportunities, assisting the development of demonstration community based projects (particularly those undertaken by females), and providing training specifically directed towards the needs of female farmers. Rural Business Development Center (RBC). Experience demonstrates that stimulating the new employment required to compensate for losses resulting from structural adjustment is a difficult task. Local populations usually have little experience of utilising their own enterprise and businesses that are set up have high failure rates. Experience also shows that agencies established to provide business support can have great success in fostering indigenous enterprise and nurturing new businesses through the critical first few years. The skills required in such agencies extend far beyond the standard business consulting functions. First, such agencies must adopt a proactive approach - if they do not, potential business opportunities are lost either through the inability of untrained individuals to express them clearly or through the fear that they will not be taken seriously. Second, the agencies must have a sound ability to be able to recognise potentially viable projects based upon little information so as to be able to screen out business ideas that have little or no chance of success. Staff seconded from successful businesses are crucial in order to fulfil this role. Third, the agency must act as a facilitator, drawing together individuals with the appropriate skills to support the development of specific business proposals. Such individuals may include those with the skills required to judge market potential and technical feasibility, as well as those that can assist businesses undertake financial analyses and prepare marketing strategies. Since different business proposals would require different expertise, rarely would such an agency maintain all the skills within the organisation. Extensive contacts are therefore vital to the operation of the agency. Currently, no such agency exists within Lithuania. The consulting companies that do exist have inevitably have concentrated their efforts on improving the communication and presenting of business proposals through the preparation of business plans and investment feasibility studies. Even where these are based upon sound models and accounting principles they usually ignore the changes occurring within the Lithuanian economy, the need to target the wants and needs of consumers and the problems of business management (especially the need for flexibility). Thus, such an agency - the Rural Business Development Centre - will be established to fulfil these functions. The agency will primarily be innovative in adopting strategies to foster new business developments thereby easing unemployment. It will however, undertake such actions as are necessary to strengthen the financial and marketing ability of managers and consultants alike. Where appropriate the RBC will pre-qualify local consulting companies to assure the quality of services supplied to Project beneficiaries. Land Reform. The current land reform programme has its roots in 1989 when it became possible for individual farmers to lease up to 50 hectares of agricultural land on favourable conditions. In 1991 a new land reform law was passed the prime objective of which was (i) to restore land and real property rights to those who had owned land prior to 1940 and to their heirs; and (ii) to privatise land that had been held by collective farms. The land laws were
 118 Project Implementation Plan further amended in 1993 and 1994 in the light of experience with operating the restitution programme. A new draft law on land registration is now (1995) in preparation. A law on mortgaging land was passed in 1992 but has not yet been implemented. A law governing physical planning and development control is only in draft form. Some ten per cent of farm lands have been surveyed to a sufficient standard for the issue of a certificate of title while a further thirty per cent have been marked out roughly on the ground. As a result of these difficulties as yet there is no active land market in Lithuania. An active land market would further the allocation of land between alternative uses on the basis of the economic returns from different activities. Lenders would also be encouraged to accept land as security for loans since valuations could be based upon real market transactions and lenders would be able to readily realise their collateral. The establishment of a land market should be encouraged by speeding up the restitution of land, the creation of an efficient land register containing only legally required and guaranteed informnation, the provision of legal support for the drafting of land related legislation; and an improved Lithuanian capability in the valuation of land. The following Technical Assistance programs shall therefore be undertaken. Legislative and Administrative Development: To foster the development of a land market in Lithuania by the provision of specialist assistance for the further development of applicable legislation and administration systems, increasing the efficiency of the system, the development of skills in the management of cadastral data and increasing the capacity for cost recovery. Land Information System: To continue the on-going development work on the land information system required to legally guarantee land transactions. Rural Credit Systems. A survey of private commercial banks indicated that whilst they were interested in participating in the Project as lenders to agro-processing companies they were unlikely to be willing to lend for on-farm development. Conversely, whilst the Agricultural Bank of Lithuania has indicated its interest in on-lending the line-of-credit to farmers and agricultural companies (as well as other eligible sub-borrowers) it currently does not satisfy World Bank eligibility criteria for inclusion in the Project as a PFI. The Government is however committed to ensure that the ABL becomes eligible to act as a PFI. It is therefore in the process of improving the capital structure of the bank through the removal of bad loans resulting from past politically directed lending from ABL's portfolio and is considering subscribing to new share capital in ABL. Technical Assistance will therefore be provided to assist the ABL in its institutional development and improve its lending procedures. The following Technical Assistance will therefore be provided. Rural Banking: To prepare a Rural Credit Manual for all PFIs. Institutional Development Program for ABL: To improve the operational structure and policies of ABL so as to be an eligible PFI under the PADP. The assistance program will include support for the development of the following twelve key areas: Planning, Budgeting and Performance; The Measurement Process, Organisational Restructuring; Human Resource

In response to the transformation of the economy from a command to a market based system the Ministry of Agriculture is restructuring its operations. Consequently a decentralised approach has been adopted to Project implementation. The Minister of Agriculture will be responsible for the Institutional and Human Resource component of the Project and will be assisted in this by the creation of a dedicated Project Management Unit (PMU) within the Ministry and a related Agricultural Technical Unit which will be independent of the Ministry. Given the limited experience of implementing World Bank projects in Lithuania, the range of donor co-financiers, the breadth of the TA package and the inexperience of potential investors, there will be a major role for World Bank supervision. The establishment of the PMU will provide effective initial implementation of the project but, to ensure that objectives are being met and that problems are rapidly identified and solved, ongoing monitoring and supervision will be required. Whilst the objectives of the Project are both clear defined and fixed, the implementation methodology to achieve these objectives has been designed to be flexible so that the Project can respond to the on- going transformation that is taking place within Lithuania. This greatly increases the importance of the supervision exercise. 34. Supervision highlights. Since this is the first World Bank project for the agricultural sector of Lithuania, there will be three supervision missions in each of the first two years. Thereafter supervision missions will be twice yearly. doc.abstracts: The main objectives of the Private Agriculture Development Project are to assist the government with the development of a viable, private agriculture sector and to foster economic growth in rural areas by providing a combination of financial and technical assistance. The project has two main components: 1) a rural credit component (RCC), which includes a US $30 million line of credit and an institutional development program for the Agricultural Bank of Lithuania (ABL) and local banks; and 2) an institutional and human resources development component (IHDC), which consists of technical assistance for land reform, extension services, marketing, business skill training, and rural employment generation and targeted poverty alleviation. The RCC aims to: 1) strengthen and restructure rural credit delivery systems; 2) develop commercial lending channels for rural credit; 3) restructure the ABL; 4) finance upgrading of technology and production facilities; 5) foster development of private farms and promote emergence of private small and medium enterprises in rural areas; and 6) provide seed money for opportunities for income and employment generation in rural areas. Finally, the objectives of the IHDC are to: 1) increase productivity, competitiveness, and marketing prospects for Lithuanian products; 2) expedite land reform and develop a mortgage system for increased access to credit; 3) increase the availability of alternative employment opportunities through retraining and diversification of farm businesses; 4) reduce rural poverty; 5) improve human skills and local institutional capacity; and 6) improve business management skills of farmers and entrepreneurs in identifying, evaluating, and pursuing business development opportunities.
